Some countryes vaunte themselves in pyes,</br>And some in meate excelle;</br>For turnippes of enormous size</br>Faire Norfolke bears the belle.
Thilke tale an olde nurse tolde to me,</br>Which I relate to you;</br>And well I weene what nurses say,</br>Is sacred all and true.
At midnighte houre a hardie knighte</br>Was pricking o'er the ley;</br>The starres and moone had lost their lighte,</br>And hee had loste his waye.
The winde full loud and sharp did blowe,</br>The clouds amaine did poure,</br>And such a night, as storyes shewe,</br>Was nivir seene before.
In vaine hee soughte full halfe the nighte,</br>Ne shelter colde hee spie:</br>Pitie it were so bolde a knyghte</br>Y-sterv'd with colde sholde dye.
Now voices straunge assaile his eare,</br>And yet ne house was nie:</br>Thoughte he, the devil himselfe is here,</br>Preserve me, God on hie!
Then summon'd hee his courage hie,</br>And thus aloud 'gan call;</br>Fays, gyauntes, demons, come not nie,</br>For I defye you all!
When from a hollow turnippe neare</br>Out jump'd a living wighte;</br>With friendly voice, and accents cleare,</br>He thus address'd the knighte.
"Sir knighte, ne demon dwelleth here,</br>Ne gyaunte keepes this house;</br>But tway poor drovers, goodman Vere,</br>And honest Robin Rouse.
"We tweyne have taken shelter here,</br>With oxen ninety-two;</br>And if you'll enter, nivir feare,</br>There's roome enough for you."</br>
